Here are the steps required to request an official transcript: Step 1: Login to Mosaic -> Step 2: Select transcript request -> Step 3: Choose processing options -> Step 4: Provide Address -> Step 5: Submit

There are two ways you can enroll in classes: using MyTimetable or using Mosaic. MyTimetable is the newest online self-service tool that allows you to find a conflict-free timetable and direct class enrolment.

For the 2020 Spring/Summer semester, you have to pay your tuition by May 25th even if youve recieved OSAP. Failure to do so will result in a 75$ Late fee due May 30th. Interest will be charged at a monthly rate of 1.2% if you still havn't paid the late fee.

For the 2020 Fall semester, you have to pay your tuition by September 25th even if youve recieved OSAP. Failure to do so will result in a 75$ Late fee due September 30th. Interest will be charged at a monthly rate of 1.2% if you still havn't paid the late fee.

For the 2021 Winter semester, you have to pay your tuition by January 25th even if youve recieved OSAP. Failure to do so will result in a 75$ Late fee due January 30th. Interest will be charged at a monthly rate of 1.2% if you still havn't paid the late fee.
If youre taking 60% or above (40% or above for students with disabilities) of a 100% course load for your program in each term, you can apply for OSAP for Full-Time Students.

If youre taking between 20% and 59% of a 100% course load for your program you can apply for OSAP for Part-Time Students. If you have a documented permanent disability and are taking between 40% and 59% of a full course load, you can choose either part-time OSAP or full-time OSAP.

Your full-time OSAP loans will begin collecting interest once you are no-longer enrolled in full-time studies. This could mean youve graduated or you’ve dropped to part-time studies, or withdrawn from school (even temporarily). You will receive a notice from the government to start repaying your loans 6 months after your last day of full-time studies.

Your part-time OSAP loans will be separate from any full-time OSAP loans you may have. These will require two separate repayment plans. Your part-time OSAP loans may begin collecting interest as soon as you are no longer enrolled in school. This could mean youve graduated or you’ve or withdrawn from school (even temporarily). You will receive a notice from the government to start repaying your loans 6 months after your last day of full-time studies.

Student loans begin collecting interest when youre no longer enrolled in full-time studies. You will be required to start repaying your loans seven months after completing full-time studies. Each year when you apply for OSAP/government aid, it tells the government that you're still a full-time student. If you don't apply one term, the government assumes you've completed full-time studies. Interest-free status confirms that you're still a full-time student and stops interest from collecting on your loans while you're still in full-time studies.
You're eligble for OSAP's interest-free status if you've received government student loans in the past and are continuing as a full-time student but not applying for OSAP/government aid.
You can view your exam schedule on Mosaic -> Student Center -> Exam Schedule. NOTE: There are no in-person April final exams. Exams will be offered in a take-home or online format.

If you miss or leave an exam for medical reasons, you must submit a Petition for Special Consideration form with supporting documentation of illness, personal or family reasons. The form is available from the Office of the Associate Dean (Studies) of your Faculty. Your petition, along with supporting documentation is normally required within 5 working days of the missed examination.
Deferred exams will be provided in the same format as in the final exams in April, that is online or remotely. Currently the designated time period is Monday June 22 to Thursday June 25, 2020.
Applications open March 16. You have until April 17th to submit your applications.

According to McMaster's new Course Repeat policy, effective September 1, 2018, students may repeat a course twice (i.e., attempt a course three times).  Cross-listed courses count as attempts. Grades from every attempt will appear on the academic transcript.  The Cumulative GPA will include only the grade earned on the most recent attempt.
To view how much you owe for tuition, follow these steps. Login into mosaic -> student center -> Account Summary -> Select the Academic Year

Set up online banking from your Canadian financial institutions website/app. Add Mcmaster University as a Bill payment and enter your 9 digit student numer as the 'Account Number'. Enter the amount you wish to pay and confirm the information.
Log on to Mosaic -> Student Center -> Finance -> Make a payment -> Follow the instructions for Credit Card Payments

You can change your program thorugh Mosaic -> Student Center -> My Academics -> Change Program/Plan Application - Please speak with an Academic Advisor first to learn how a program change will affect your course selection and the duration of your degree, and to confirm that the switch you want to make is possible.
For a required fee you can request a duplicate or replacement degree parchment, diploma or certificate.
Follow these steps to view your class schedule: Login to Mosaic -> Student Center -> Academics -> Class Schedule -> Select Term
Follow these steps to view your final grades: Login to Mosaic -> Student Center -> Academics -> Grades -> Select Term

Unless otherwise specified in the program information, applicants will apply for transfer or for a second degree using the online 105 application via the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC). For all application dates and deadlines, plus information about any supplemental application requirements, please refer to the current Application Guide for McMaster University on the OUAC 105 application site.
A scholarship (also called an 'award') is based on your academic and extracurricular achievements. Some are automatic, some require an application.
To apply for bursaries, follow these steps: Login to Mosaic -> Student Center -> Finances -> Apply for financial aid -> General Bursary / Work Programs -> Apply

To provide Verification of Degree, you may do so through the Mosaic Student Centre > My Academics > Enrolment/Financial Letters > Degree Awarded Letter. This is only available the day after your convocation ceremony.
Students can apply for scholarships via the online aid application in the Mosaic Student Centre. Go to ‘Apply for Financial Aid’ to access the application
In Mosaic, current students can navigate to Student Centre> Academics > Search to search for classes. The timetable for the 2019/20 academic year will be available on June 12.

MacDrive is McMaster Universitys cloud server where you can share your files with us securely. Similar to DropBox, it allows you to securely submit forms, requests and supporting documentation for review and assessment.
You can request a formal name change on your student record by completing an uploading the Name Change Form to MacDrive.

Congratulations! You are on your way to crossing the sclasse and graduating from McMaster University! Go to the following website https://registrar.mcmaster.ca/grad/. Be sure to fill out the GIC, confirm all day-of event details, find out the specific ceremony you should be attending and everything that your guests need to know! If you need support contact convocation@mcmaster.ca

McMaster is deeply committed to supporting our community during the rapid changes taking place worldwide due to COVID-19. Here's an FAQ dealing with the matter - https://registrar.mcmaster.ca/covid-19/ These frequently asked questions are specific to McMaster undergraduate and graduate students. We will continue to update FAQs as needed.
To view your GPA, you can request an unofficial transcript or calculate yourself at https://gradecalc.info/ca/on/mcmaster/gpa_calc.pl
To view information about McMaster's Co-op Program, please go to this website - https://www.eng.mcmaster.ca/co-op-career/co-op-program
The McMaster Work Program (you may hear it called 'work/study') gives students who demonstrate financial need opportunities to work on campus during the fall/winter terms and over the summer.

You must be approved for the McMaster Work Program BEFORE you can apply for any work-program jobs. Applications for work-program approval are done in Mosaic. The first step to applying for the Work Program (and scholarships and bursaries) is completing the personal profile in your online aid application Mosaic. This application opens on Aug. 12 for the coming academic year (September-August).
Understanding the difference between a dropped course and a cancelled course is financially critical. Go to this website to read about it - https://registrar.mcmaster.ca/course-cancellation-schedule/
If you have decided to withdraw from a session or from the university entirely, you must first remove your courses from MOSIAC (otherwise charges will remain).

For the B.Tech Program, there are 24 courses required to complete your 4 year McMaster University degree. 17 core technical topics include mathematics, software design and testing, data analysis, networking, security, computer architecture, and advanced programming concepts such as parallel software architectures and real-time systems. Seven management courses complement your studies. Now offering courses in data science and artificial intelligence.

You can speak to a counsellor by booking a 15 minute consultation appointment. Call 905-525-9140 x 27700 or visit PGCLL 210 to book. Together you will be able to explore support options and decide on your pathways to receive support (see Pathways to Care below). Follow up appointment time may vary.

If you enroll into the B.Tech Software Engineering program you can learn about the design, development, and deployment of computing systems in the software products and computing infrastructure areas from both technical and managerial points of view.
